questions.text: The causes of Adynamic intestinal obstruction is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pseudo-obstruction Causes of intestinal obstruction: Dynamic Intraluminal Fecal impactionForeign bodies Bezoars [Option A] Gallstones Intramural Stricture Malignancy [Option D] Intussusception Volvulus [Option C] Extramural Bands/adhesions Hernia Adynamic Paralytic ileus Pseudo-obstruction

Highyeild:

Intestinal pseudo-obstruction ( IPO ) is a clinical syndrome caused by severe impairment of intestinal motility, resulting in small intestinal dilatation without any mechanical obstruction. The term " chronic " is sometimes used to make the definition clearer. IPO can be classified as primary or secondary. Primary IPO is rare and associated with enteric myopathies and neuropathies, while the cause of idiopathic IPO is unknown. Secondary IPO is linked to various underlying medical conditions, including connective tissue disease, radiation injury, amyloidosis, autonomic neuropathies such as diabetes and paraneoplasia, and infections like Chagas' disease .

Extraedge:

Management of intestinal pseudo-obstruction includes: Nutrition support through enteral or parenteral means. Analgesia , with an effort to avoid opioids. Prokinetics may be considered, but they are generally not very effective. Antibiotics may be used to treat bacterial overgrowth. Immunotherapy may be used in specific cases with an inflammatory component, although the data is limited. Psychological support, including patient support groups, may be helpful for patients. Palliative care may be appropriate for some patients with advanced disease. Surgery is only considered in very selected cases.

questions.text: The most common intussusception in adults is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Colocolic An intussusception is composed of three parts: The entering or inner tube ( intussusceptum ); The returning or middle tube; The sheath or outer tube ( intussuscipiens ). The part that advances is the apex, the mass is the intussusception and the neck is the junction of the entering layer with the mass. Intussusception may be anatomically defined according to the site and extent of invagination.

Highyeild:

Colocolic intussusception is more common in adults than in children. The degree of ischemia caused by intussusception depends on the tightness of the invagination, which is typically greatest as it passes through the ileocaecal valve. On CT scanning, the " target sign " may be visible and is pathognomonic (distinctive and specific) for intussusception. Occasionally, an asymptomatic intussusception can be observed on CT scanning in adults, which may be transient or intermittent.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . In most children, the intussusception is ileocolic. In adults, colocolic intussusception is more common. The degree of ischemia is dependent on the tightness of the invagination, which is usually greatest as it passes through the ileocaecal valve. On CT scanning the target sign may be evident and if present is pathognomonic. It is worth noting that, rarely, intussusception has been noted on CT scanning in asymptomatic adults. Option: C & D. Can not be the answer.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding volvulus:

options.label: A
options.text: Volvulus is a twisting or axial rotation of a portion of the bowel about its mesentery.

options.label: B
options.text: Primary is more common than secondary

options.label: C
options.text: Primary occurs secondary to congenital malrotation of the gut

options.label: D
options.text: Commonest spontaneous type in adults is sigmoid.

questions.correct_answer: B. Primary is more common than secondary
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primary is more common than secondary Volvulus: A volvulus is a twisting or axial rotation of a portion of the bowel about its mesentery. The rotation causes obstruction to the lumen (>180° torsion) and if tight enough also causes vascular occlusion in the mesentery (>360° torsion). Bacterial fermentation adds to the distension and increasing intraluminal pressure impairs capillary perfusion. Mesenteric veins become obstructed as a result of the mechanical twisting and thrombosis results and contribute to the ischemia. Volvuli may be primary or secondary. The primary form occurs secondary to congenital malrotation of the gut, abnormal mesenteric attachments, or congenital bands. Examples include volvulus neonatorum, caecal volvulus, and sigmoid volvulus. A secondary volvulus, which is the more common variety, is due to the rotation of a segment of the bowel around an acquired adhesion or stoma. It may involve the small intestine, caecum, or sigmoid colon; neonatal midgut volvulus secondary to midgut malrotation is life-threatening The commonest spontaneous type in adults is sigmoid Sigmoid volvulus can be relieved by decompression per anum Surgery is required to prevent or relieve ischemia.

Highyeild:

Volvulus is a condition in which a segment of the gastrointestinal tract twists or torsions, leading to obstruction of the intestinal lumen and potentially compromising blood flow to the affected area. The small intestine, caecum, and sigmoid colon are common sites of volvulus. In neonates, midgut volvulus resulting from abnormal rotation of the midgut during embryonic development can be a life-threatening emergency. In adults, sigmoid volvulus is the most common spontaneous form of volvulus. Sigmoid volvulus typically presents with abdominal pain, distension, and obstipation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, C, & D. Are true statements

Extraedge:

Treatment of sigmoid volvulus often involves decompression via the rectum, using a flexible tube or a sigmoidoscope. Surgical intervention may be necessary to prevent or relieve ischemia in cases of severe or recurrent volvulus, particularly in the presence of underlying anatomical abnormalities or motility disorders.
